newsitem.title: UK: PRESS DIGEST - Evening Standard - May 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Evening Standard - May 23.

text.p: Prepared for Reuters by The Broadcast Monitoring Company

A 12 year old girl was murdered by a burglar at her home in Hammersmith last night. The child's father, who is a Bosnian refugee, arrived home when the man was still in his house, and despite a frantic chase the suspect escaped after hijacking a car. Detectives have launched a murder hunt and appealed for witnesses.

Sources say that the Serious Fraud Office are looking carefully at a co-op set up by Andrew Regan during his failed takeover bid for the Co-operative Wholesale Society. If it decides to conduct an official investigation, it will be the first by the SFO into any aspect of the CWS bid.

Virgin Rail is to invite five companies to bid for a 750m stg contract to build 100 new high-speed trains, plus additional rolling stock for the West Coast and Cross Country franchises. The five companies comprise three European operations and two North American ones, and all have indicated the trains will be assembled in Britain, creating up to 5000 jobs.

Sterling's fall of nearly three pfennigs yesterday, following news that a rogue trader accidentally sold 200m stg or 300m stg of Deutschmarks and that export demand was at its lowest since November 1993, was not replicated in the Far East. Instead, the market digested the dramatic slide of the dollar against the yen which has taken place this week.

News Corp's share price has been sliding in Australia, despite the announcement of a bumper A$373 million (185 million stg) quarterly profit. The slide is the result of a feeling that Murdoch has reneged on his February statement that he was not considering acquisitions, in the light of the attempt to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers and a rumoured $1bn deal to buy the US Family Channel.
